title: Budget 2018: Money Saving Expert Martin Lewis' five things you should have spotted
text:

Philip Hammond has said the "era of austerity is finally coming to an end", in his last Budget before Brexit.
The Chancellor spoke for more than an hour and then released a 100+ page document outlining his plans.
Now, MoneySavingExpert.com founder Martin Lewis has been trawling through the document to find out how the Budget will really affect you.
In an interview with 5Live, he revealed there was a lot more you need to know about in the document, the Mirror reports .
“We've just had a 10-page speech from Philip Hammond ,” he said. (Image: PA)
“But the real Budget is a 100 to 200 page red book with all the details in.”
These are the five key points he has uncovered from the report: 1. Personal allowance “The big one”
For the past few years, the amount you can earn before you're hit with income tax has been rising. And in April 2019 it will shoot up from £11,850 to £12,500.
What does that mean? “A £130 a year gain for anyone earning over £12,500,” Martin explained.
There was even more cash for the better off – with the point you start paying 40% income tax moving from £46,350 to £50,000. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
“Which means another £730 in the pay packets of people who are above £50,000,” Martin added.
However, the super-rich won't get the full benefit – for once – with people making more than £100,000 not benefiting as much or even at all. 2. Universal Credit “They are changing it”
It's fair to say Martin isn't a fan of Universal Credit.
“I'm one of those whose been ranting about the absolute disaster Universal Credit has been for many of the vulnerable people in this country – they simply haven't got it right and it should never have been introduced if it wasn't right – it's too dangerous and too damaging,” he said.
But Martin pointed out: “They are changing it, both the transition process and the in-work allowance.
“What that basically means is that if you're on Universal credit you will now be allowed to earn £1,000 more a year from work before your universal credit starts to decrease.”
What's that worth? Around £600 a year to the people affected by the change, Martin said. Read More
